question.content:
[[☃ image 1]]

The Silk Road, a system of trade routes that changed the course of history, extended over 4,000 miles from ancient China to the Mediterranean Sea. From around 200 B.C.E. to 1453 C.E., the Silk Road allowed people from Asia, the Middle East, and parts of Africa and Europe to trade goods like silk, tea, spices, cloth, and jade. 

This ancient superhighway [[☃ definition 1]] the exchange not only of goods, but of groundbreaking ideas and inventions as well. Paper, which was invented in China, spread to the West via the Silk Road. Paper revolutionized communication by making writing materials cheaper and more widely available. The compass was another invention that traveled the Silk Road, leading to its widespread use. Having a [[☃ definition 2]] was like having a tiny treasure map that could guide merchants and explorers across the vast, unpredictable [[☃ definition 3]] of the ancient world. 

The Silk Road was even responsible for the spread of different religions and philosophies. Buddhism, now one of the major religions of East Asia, was introduced to China by Buddhist monks traveling along the Silk Road. The Silk Road made possible an exchange of goods and ideas that shaped not only the ancient world, but also our own.



**Which detail from the text best explains *how* the Silk Road “shaped not only the ancient world, but also our own”?**

choices.content: "The Silk Road, a system of trade routes that changed the course of history, extended over 4,000 miles from ancient China to the Mediterranean Sea."
choices.clue: This detail doesn’t best explain how the Silk Road shaped the ancient and modern worlds. This sentence states that the Silk Road “changed the course of history,” but it doesn’t explain *how* the Silk Road changed history.

choices.content: "From around 200 B.C.E. to 1453 C.E., the Silk Road allowed people from Asia, the Middle East, and parts of Africa and Europe to trade goods like silk, tea, spices, cloth, and jade."
choices.clue: This detail doesn’t best explain how the Silk Road shaped the ancient and modern worlds. This sentence shows how the Silk Road affected the ancient world by allowing people from all over to trade goods, but it doesn’t show how the Silk Road shaped the modern world.

choices.content: "Having a compass was like having a tiny treasure map that could guide merchants and explorers across the vast, unpredictable terrain of the ancient world."
choices.clue: This detail doesn’t best explain how the Silk Road shaped the ancient and modern worlds. This sentence shows how the Silk Road helped spread the use of the compass, making it easier to navigate the ancient world. It doesn’t show how the Silk Road shaped the modern world.

choices.content: "Buddhism, now one of the major religions of East Asia, was introduced to China by Buddhist monks traveling along the Silk Road."
choices.clue: **This is the best choice.** This sentence shows that the Silk Road shaped the ancient world by introducing Buddhism to China. The sentence also says that Buddhism is “now one of the major religions of East Asia,” which shows that the spread of Buddhism via the Silk Road in ancient times affected the current popularity of Buddhism.

options.definition: fa·cil·i·ta·ted (fuh-SIL-uh-tay-tud): made easier or more likely
a device that helps people navigate by showing them their direction of travel
ter·rain (tuh-RANE): land with specific physical features
